poem:
**Echoes of the Liverbirds**

Strings reverberate in hidden booths,  
where harmonies of unseen goddesses play,  
above the din of Beatlemania's proof,  
their voices twine like whispers in the hay.  
Val, defiant, strums the chords of truth,  
lost legends in the shadows of Massey Hall,  
where girls do play guitars,  
and echoes won't fade at all.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Girls Don’t Play Guitars review – Liverbirds musical is just ho-hum Despite being one of the world’s first all-female rock groups, electrifying concerts in the UK, Europe and the world during the 1960s, the Liverbirds and their legacy have been dwarfed by that of fellow Liverpool band the Beatles. Ian Salmon musical Girls Don’t Play Guitars attempts to make their case. A guitar outline encircles centre stage, lassoing the girls – tearaway Val (Molly-Grace Cutler),". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
